I was in Birdcage-walk, and saw a soldier and a female standing there—I had not gone many yards before the female called out that the soldier had taken her umbrella, and was going away with it, and asked me to go and get it from him—he was walking away with it—I called to him, and he com
menced running—I called "Stop thief"—the policeman asked what was the matter—I said he had taken an umbrella, and he pursued him—he was little in liquor I think—it was the prisoner.

BASIL MIDDLETON . I am an officer. I heard the cry of "Stop thief!" and went up to Birch, who told me that the soldier had run away with the umbrella—I went after him, and overtook him in Cartwright-street—I asked him who the umbrella belonged to—he put his back against the rails, and tried to drop it down the railings—I took it up, and took him back to the prosecutrix—I asked if it belonged to her, and she said "Yet"—he said he had taken it for a lark.

Prisoner's Defence. I was in liquor at the time it happened, but as far as I can recollect, I met the female-what I said to her I cannot say—she said she would go to the barracks and report me—I think I took it out of her hand to prevent her going to report me.

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined Six Months.

1985.
JOHN VIVIAN was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John ThompSon, about the hour of ten in the night of the llth of August, at St. Luke, with inttet to steal, and stealing therein, 18 spoons, value 9l. 10s.; 16 forks, value 10l.; 6 knives, value 2l. 10s.; 3 ladles, value 2l. 10s.; 1 fish-slice, value 1l. 10s.; 1 coffee-pot, value 7s.; and two wine-strainers, value 5s.; the goods of the said John Thompson.
MR. PAYNE. conducted the Prosecution.

MARY CORNER . I am the wife of John Corner, and was in the service of Mr. John Thompson, of Albion-terrace, King's-road, Chelsea—the pri
soner is my brother, and was in the habit of coming to see me about once a week or fortnight, at master's house—I saw him there on the Tuesday before the examination—on the Saturday night before I went before the Magistrate on Monday, I left the house between nine and ten o'clock—I will not be positive it was after nine o'clock—it was after eight o'clock—I had the care of the house—Mr. Thompson was out of town—I left no body in the house when I went out—I pulled the door after me, but I will not be positive whether it was shut—I came back before ten o'clock, and found the door shut—I opened it with a key, and went in, and missed the property stated in the indictment—it had been wrapped up is a leather-when I went out it was safe on a large table—I should think it worth about 20l.—I spoke to the policeman directly, and he came in and examined the house—my mother had been with me that day—on the Sun
day morning, between nine and ten o'clock, I went with my mother over to Tooting to my brother's lodging—he asked us why we came there a early in the morning—my mother said we had lost some plate—he said he had not seen it—he at last took us to Wandsworth-common, kicked a turf with his feet, and there was the plate, wrapped up in the leather as before—we all three came along the road together, and met a policeman—my brother then turned away from us, and was going away from the common—the policeman went after him, and brought him back—he then came after my mother and me, and took us all to the station-house—I think the plate is master's—it is the same leather and the same plate that was in the box.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY of larceny only. Aged 24.—Recommended to mercy.
Confined Six Months.

1986.
JULIA KEATING was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of August, at St. Mary, Islington, 7 sovereigns, the monies of
Lydia Catherine Lemoyne, her mistress, in her dwelling-house.

LYDIA CATHERINE. LEMOYNE . I am single, and live in Canonbury-lane, in the parish of St. Mary, Islington. The prisoner was my cook I left home on the 12th of August, and went to church—I returned in the middle of the day—I went to church again in the evening, and when I returned, found the prisoner intoxicated in the fore-court—she was brought in and put to bed, and after counting my money in my box, I found seven sovereigns had been taken away—the box was still locked—I believe I had left my keys in my room, but I am not exactly sure—I sent for a constable—we went into the prisoner's room, and found six sovereigns and nine shillings and sixpence in her pocket—she was taken to the station-house—I found my keys hanging in a drawer in a chest in my own room.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Had not you left them there? A. I do not know—I might possibly have done so—I had seen them last before I went to church in the morning—I found them in my drawer after the morning service—the housemaid was at church in the morning—my sister lives with me—we keep a school—we share the profits of the school,

but the seven sovereigns were my own, and not connected with the school—I had counted my money on Saturday night, the last thing before I went to bed—it was in a common wooden box—the money taken was my own—there were forty-two sovereigns in the box; eighteen were in a purse, and there were six papers, each containing four sovereigns-five of the papers had been opened, and one sovereign extracted from each—it was not joint property—the prisoner was insensibly drunk.
ANN BECKWITH . I am the prosecutrix's servant. I was at home on this Sunday—I found the prisoner drunk, and took her to bed-her pocket dropped—I took it up, and the policeman was sent for.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you at home all the evening during your mistress's absence? A. I was at church in the morning—I was at home in the evening—the prisoner went out to go to church, and I saw no more of her till mistress came home, and found her drunk in the fore-court.

JOHN GIBLETT . I am a policeman. I was sent for, and found the prisoner lying on the bed, drunk—I found a letter in her pocket—after she dressed herself, I took her pocket from under her pillow, and found six sovereigns, nine shillings and sixpence in silver, and sixpence-half-penny in copper, in it.

GUILTY . Aged 43.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1987.
JOHN HARRISON was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of August, 1 umbrella, value 5s., the goods of
Philip Newman; and that he had been before convicted of felony, to which he pleaded

GUILTY .*—
Transported for Seven Years.

1988.
ROBERT METCALFE was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of July, 1 jacket, value 2s.; 1 pair of half-boots, value 6s., the goods of
Charles Martin; and 1 hat, value 4s.; 3lbs. weight of pork, value 1s. 6d.; and 3lbs. weight of bread, value 3d., the goods of
Michael Lewington; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined Three Months.

1989.
JAMES MILLHOUSE was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of August, 6 towels, value 4s.; 1 coat, value 3s.; 1 table-cloth, value 2s.; 1 pinafore, value 6d.; 1 basket, value 6d., the goods of
Philip Spencer Harrison: 1 pair of stockings, value 1s., the goods of
William Baldwin: 1 gown, value 4s.; 2 petticoats, value 4s., the goods of
Ann Bundock: 5 shirts, value 30s.; 3 pairs of stockings, value 2s.; and 1 pair of drawers, value 2s.; the goods of
Frances Smith; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Three Months.

1990.
WILLIAM FORD was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of August, 1 adze, value 2s., the goods of the
London Dock Company.

RICHARD NANCARROW . I am an officer of the Customs. I stopped the prisoner on the 10th of August, at West-garden-gate, London Docks, and found on him a cooper's adze—he said he had taken it from one of
the cooper's mates, and had knocked the handle out to grind the adze—that he had put it in his pocket in a lark, and did not know it was there.

GEORGE DIX . I am a constable in the London Docks. I received the prisoner in charge. I asked him where he got the adze—he said, on the quay—I think he said the East quay—I went there, and Sanders had lost his adze—it is marked with the London Dock Company's mark.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had you known the prisoner working in the dock? A. No, I might have seen him working there.
THOMAS SANDERS . I am a cooper in the employ of Mr. Haywood—he contracts for the London Dock Company's coopering. I left my tools on the head of a puncheon in the Docks—I missed this adze.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know this man before? A. No, he was a stranger in the Dock.

WILLIAM ALLARS . I know this adze, it is one of a dozen which be
longed to the London Dock Company
HENRY ASHCROFT . I am vault-keeper of the rum vault, East Vaults, London Docks. The prisoner worked on the quay at our vault, but has left about three months, with a good character.
NOT GUILTY .

1991.
SAMUEL CRAWCOUR was indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 4th of August, of an evil-disposed person, 2lbs. weight of tea, value 10s.; and 4th of weight of tortoiseshell, value 10s.; the goods of the
London Dock Company.
MESSRS. ADOLPHUS. and BALLANTINE. conducted the Prosecution.

CHARLES ROBERTSON DUNKINSON . I am a Customs gate-keeper at the London Dock. I was on duty at the west entrance, on the afternoon of Saturday, the 4th of August—I saw the prisoner coming out, and in con
sequence of something I observed, I stopped him about half-past four o'clock—I asked him what he had in his hat—he said, "A little tea"—I then asked what he had in his pockets—he said, "A little tea"—I searched him, and found in his hat about 1 1/2 lbs. weight of tea, and in his pockets two packets of tea, about 1/4 lb.—they were wrapped up in whitey-brown paper—I then asked what he had got in his stomach—he said, "Apiece of tortoiseshell, "and he gave me this piece of tortoiseshell from between his shirt and trowsers—I asked where he got the tea and tortoiseshell—he said the mate of a ship, from China, gave them him—I asked if he could show us the ship—he said, "Yes, and it appeared to have tea in the hold"—I went with him, and when we got to the East quay, he said, "It is no use tak
ing you any farther; to tell you the truth, one Mr. Avery gave it me".
COURT. Q. Did he speak of having all the goods from Avery? A. I understood he had them both from one or the other party.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Does tea come from China? A. Yes, and I believe tortoiseshell does—the prisoner is the son of a re
spectable man, I have heard-his father was at the office—it is an al
most every-day occurrence for mates of ships to make up samples, and get persons to smuggle them out—these small parcels of tea look like samples but the parcel in the hat was so large it must have been seen by any person-tortoiseshell pays a duty, I believe.

JOHN CLEMENTS . I am a constable. I went with the prisoner and Mr. Dunkinson, round the Docks, for the prisoner to point out the ship from which he got the tea-when we got to the East quay, he said, "It is no

use my taking you about in this way, I will tell you the truth, Avery gave me the tea and the tortoiseshell"-Avery is a manager of teas at No. 2 ware house, London Docks—he has no right to give any tea away—I took the prisoner to the watch-house, and then went and found Avery—I took him to the watch-house, and said to the prisoner, "Is that the man that gave you the tea and tortoiseshell?"—the prisoner said, "Yes"-Avery said with surprise, "I give you the tea!"—the prisoner remained silent-A very said, "It is false, by G-."

FIANCIS HILL . I am an officer of the Customs at the tea warehouse. I saw the prisoner on the 4th of August, in the tea-warehouse—he asked A. No he was for Mr. Avery—I told him he was in the building, and if he would go on, he would find him—the tea produced is worth about 10s.—the duty is 2s. 11d. per pound—the teas in bond are the property of the merchants—they are in the custody of the London Dock Company.

JOHN TREEMER . I am in the employ of the London Dock Company. I saw the prisoner in the warehouse No. 2, on Saturday, the 4th of Au
gust—I know Avery—I had left him a few minutes before in the ware-house, on business—I saw the prisoner in Avery's room—I believe he was acquainted with him—I had seen him in company with him before that day—this paper which is round the tea, found on the prisoner, is si
milar to what is used in the Dock warehouse for papering green tea—we had chests of tea opened in No. 2 warehouse the day before for tareing—the officers of the establishment had access to that warehouse while the tea was tareing, and so had Avery—he was superintendent of that ware-house—I cannot say how many chests of tea were opened, but of the de
scription of tea found on the prisoner, we might have perhaps twenty opened on the Thursday and the Friday—this is precisely of the same de
scription as that in the chests-when the tea is tared, the chests are en
tirely emptied—the tea is weighed and put in again, and the chests are nailed down-Avery was present—there were no chests of this particular description of tea opened on Saturday the 4th of August—the value of this tea found on the prisoner is about 10s., including the duty, which is 2s. 1d. a pound—it is green tea.

Cross-examined. Q. Is not that a good price for it? A. It is what I think it would fetch in the trade—I heard the officer say, there was about 2lbs. of it—it is young hyson—there are two sorts of tea which are more common, twankay and hyson-skin—it is perhaps two months since we had any tea of this sort open before in that warehouse—I cannot tell what had been opened in the other warehouse—there is only one other warehouse that has tea in it.

JOHN COOK . I am a foreman in the London Docks. Some tortoise-shell was opened for public sale on the 25th and 27th of July—some part of it was left at the Docks—this piece found on the prisoner is of the same kind, but it ran of various shapes and sizes—the officers of the Company had access to the place where this tortoiseshell was kept-Avery came there sometimes, but very seldom-tea and tortoiseshell are sometimes left on board the ships, and not taken to the warehouses directly—after the sale, the tortoiseshell was packed into the cases, weighed, and put away-no person could have got at that tortoiseshell in any private man
ner on the 4th of August—they must have broken a chest open of con
siderable size.
EDWARD WILLIAM SIMMONS . I was present on the first examination

of the prisoner, at the Thames police-office—he made a statement, on the 4th of August, which I took down, and it was signed by the Magistrate—this is it—(looking at it)—(read)-'The prisoner says, 'I had them given to me by Avery, in the tea-warehouse, about ten minutes to three o'clock—he gave me the tortoiseshell as well as the tea—that is truth'"—on the 6th of August the prisoner was examined again, and he then said, in reply to an observation made by Avery—(reading)-"He did not give me the property, but I thought he had the power to let me pass at the gate—it was given me by a sailor, a mate of a ship—I don't know the ship I had it brought to me—I was sitting on a barrel, on the side of the Dock."
RICHARD AVERY . I am manager of the tea department, at No. 2 warehouse. I have had a knowledge of the prisoner the last five months.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you employed in the Docks at the present time? A. I am not.

COURT. Q. you. need not answer the question, you may use your own discretion. Did you give the prisoner the tea or the tortoiseshell pro
duced? A. On my oath I did not—I had not the slightest knowledge whatever of his having it—I never gave any facility to him to take any thing out of the Dock—I am so surrounded that it would be impossible for me to do it—the prisoner might have called, on me—I know, as a matter of fact, that goods are smuggled through the Docks from the ships.
NOT GUILTY .

1992.
JOHN BILL was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of August, 2 pints of brandy, value 5s., and 1 pint of wine, value 2s., the goods of the
London Dock Company, his masters.
MR. BALLANTINE. conducted the Prosecution.

GEORGE DIX . I am a policeman. In consequence of information I went with a man named Clements to the East Vault Office, London Docks, on the 14th of August—the prisoner was employed in that office as a clerk—I asked Clements to examine the prisoner's desk—it is a large desk which extends from one side of the box to the other—I should think it is about eight feet—there are others sit there besides him—there is a small cupboard under his desk from the ground up to the desk—the prisoner un
locked the door of the cupboard—I searched it all round, and I found a small bag, but nothing of consequence—I perceived that the inside of the cup
board did not extend so high as the outside-by pulling a drawer out in the desk, he could get to the top of this cupboard-while the drawer was closed I could not see any opening—I pulled the drawer out entirely, and saw a board which appeared to have been recently planed—I pulled up that board, put my hand in, and found three bottles containing two pints of brandy, and one pint of wine—I examined the cupboard well—there was no means of getting to the place where I found the bottles without opening the drawer—the desk does not open—it was by pulling the drawer out, I got to the top of the cupboard, and the prisoner unlocked the drawer—I asked whether he could give any account of these bottles—he said he knew nothing of them, nor yet of the place—he had been in the employment of the Docks a long time—he came there when quite a lad.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Were you the first officer em
ployed, or was Mr. Hogg? A. I have no knowledge of any one but my
self

and Clements—I had a letter from Mr. Edwards, but I have not got it present—I believe it is in the hands of the solicitor—I have seen a paper called the "Town"—I believe I have seen the number of the 18th of august—I do not doubt that I have—I see most of them.

Q. Look at this letter in it—(handing the paper to the witness)-did you sea that? A. Yes—I received the letter signed Edwards before I saw this paper or heard of it—I received the letter on Friday, the 10th of August—(looking at a letter)—this is the letter I received then—I know Mr. lames Edwards—he is here in Court—he is foreman to Lady Carman—I believe he has other names besides Edwards—I believe his names are Edwards Andrew Pearson—it was in consequence of this letter that I made my inquiries and my searches.

Q. Did you learn from James Edwards that the prisoner had written a letter to the "Town" about the clerks in the office, and that he would give him a turn? A. I did not—I know Betts—I cannot say whether he is an acquaintance of Pearson's—I know Groom—I cannot say whether he is an acquaintance of Betts's.
COURT. Q. You. went to search the prisoner's desk in consequence of' receiving that letter? A. Yes—I heard nothing of the "Town" till the Monday.
JOHN CLEMENTS . I was present at the finding of these bottels—the prisoner said he knew nothing about them, and did not know even of the existence of the place.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe you searched him first on the Monday evening? A. Yes; and found nothing on him—I had searched the seat before that evening, but did not find the secret place.

ALEXANDER STEWART BETTS . I am an extra clerk in the East Vault Office, London Docks—I was present when Dix found the bottles of wine and brandy over a drawer in the prisoner's desk—the prisoner kept the key of the drawer—I have noticed that the prisoner has been in the habit of locking his drawer latterly when he went out and taking the key with him—the key was on a bunch of keys—I saw the bottles found—this is one of them—(looking at a bottle)—I have seen this bottle before at the office in the prisoner's possession—it was then empty—I saw it a fortnight or three weeks before, in the prisoner's cupboard I think.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had he been in the London Dock? A. I cannot say—he has been in our place about ten months—I have known him in the Docks about two years—he and I were on very good terms as clerks sitting together—I could not help feeling sorry when the officers made this discovery—I was a good deal surprised—there have not been any irregularities in the Docks to my knowledge—the prisoner is rather given to writing lampoons, and it seems according to the "Town," that he has been writing them against his friends.

Q. Have you any means of knowing that he has written lampoons against his friends and against yourself, except from the "Town?" A. yes—I saw him writing a paper I think on, the Saturday week previous to its appearing in the "Town"-at least he was writing it on the Thursday and Friday, and I suppose it was sent on the Saturday—there was only the prisoner and I sat on that side of the desk, and on the other side Mr. Treble and Mr. Patrick sat.
Q. As you saw he was writing on the Thursday and Friday, did you suspect he was going to send a lampoon? A. No—we sat so close that it
was impossible for one to write without the other seeing him—I happened to catch a glimpse of the word "Town," and having seen the paper called the "Town," that arrested my attention.

Q. Did you crib the draft of it from under his portfolio? A. I did—he wrote it and kept a copy of it—that is the fact—it began as this letter does—Mr. Rundle is foreman of the vault, and I am casting clerk-when I cribbed this letter, I showed it to Mr. Mitchel, a superior officer, but to no one else—I have not had it since—I do not know Edwards—I know Pearson—he is a common man—I had some conversation with him about the letter-everybody in the Docks knew it—I do not know how soon after an officer was desired to be in attendance to see if he could find any thing on a gentleman wearing grey breeches—(looking at a letter.)I saw this at the police-office—I cannot say whether Pearson wrote it—it is dis
guised—I think some of the letters are very like his writing—it is a long time since I saw his writing.

Q. There is a secret bottom to this drawer or top to the cupboard, how long has it been there? A. I cannot say—I have known it there two years, ever since I have been there—that may be a nice place to put a bottle in, to get a man into a scrape, that writes in the Town—I do not know whether Pearson knew of that place, or whether the superior officer did—I never told them of it—I mentioned it at the Thames police, and to the constables—I do not know of any other secret place—I have not got one.
NOT GUILTY .

1993.
JOHN M'CORMACK,
WILLIAM SLOANE , and
GEORGE SMITH , were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of July, 1 sheet, value 5s.; 6 spoons, value 12s.; 1 tea-pot, value 5l., the goods of
John Soy, in a vessel, called the Royal Adelaide, on the navigable river Thames.-2nd COUNT,. stating them to be the goods of
Mary Coatsworth.
MESSRS. CLARKSON. and BALLANTINE. conducted the Prosecution.

THOMAS LAWSON . I was a seaman on board the Royal Adelaide steam vessel. She was lying in the river, off St. Katharine's Docks—the there prisoners were employed as porters, in stowing the cargo—they were all three working in the hold with me—I was called up to get tea, at half-past five o'clock, and after that I sat down to smoke on the grating-Sloane came up with a sheet under his arm—I asked what he had got—he said some washed linen—I took it from him—it was a sheet marked "C. R."—I said there was something going on wrong—I went down into the hold, and saw M'Cormack with something, and asked what he had—he said he had nothing—I said he had something he ought not to have—he put it in his pocket—I took it out of his right-hand pocket, and it was half a dozen silver spoons—I called the mate and found a tea-pot lying by two cases, by M'Cormack's feet-Smith was on deck at that time, at his duty-Coyle and I examined the hold, and found a chest which had been broken—I did not observe any thing on the top of the chest—there appeared to have been things taken out—there was a space in the chest.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you given either of these men any thing to drink? A. No-no rum, nor wine, nor any sugar to eat-M'Cormack did not tell me he was going to give these spoons to the mate—he put them in his pocket, before my face—I cannot say how many. persons were on board-no one was in the hold but M'Cormack.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Sloane came up from the hold? A. Yes, and on taking the sheet from him, I went immediately down into the hold-john Soy is captain of that ship.

JOHN BARTLETT . I am a Thames police-constable. I was called on board the Adelaide, on Friday, the 6th of July, at half-past eight at night—these articles were delivered to me, and I took the three prisoners—I searched Smith on the deck, and found on him two ounces of tobacco—I asked M'Cormack where he got the spoons—he said he saw a piece of paper on one of the cases, and when he came to overhaul it, he found it to contain spoons, and put them into his pocket-Sloane said he picked up the sheet lying by the water-closet—he thought it was washed linen, and intended to give it to the steward.

THOMAS COYLE . I am shipping clerk to the agent of the Dublin and London Steam-packet Company. I was on board the Adelaide on the 6th of July—I received the chest—there was a ticket on it marked "No. 14," and in the evening it was discovered to be broken—the name of the cap
tain is John Soy.

CHARLES HENRY FALCONER . I am a Thames police-surveyor. Bart
lett reported to me that he had these men, and I sent for them—I told them I understood they were charged with breaking open a plate chest, on boarcl the Adelaide, but to be careful what they said-Sloane said, "I was going to the water-closet, and found the sheet, I kept it as was my duty, till I saw some of the crew, and when I came on deck I gave it to Lawson"-M'Cormack said, "I was going for a south-wester in another part of the hold, and on my way I found a parcel of spoons, I had them in my hand, but never put them into my pocket"-Smith gave an account of something found on him, but not of these things.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe that was a bit of tobacco? A. Yes.

SARAH CRAWLEY . I live in Bridge-street, Greenwich. Mrs. Coats-worth was my mistress—she lived at Mrs. Smallwood's, at Greenwich—she left for Falmouth on the 7th—I was with her till the Friday morn
ing preceding—I corded up all her boxes but one large chest, which was too heavy for me—I saw it at her house before it went away—there was too direction on it to go to Mr. Coyle, to go on board the steam-packet—this sheet—(looking at it)-is hers—this tea-pot and spoons are hers—they were to go by the Royal Adelaide.

JOHN OSBORNE . lam manager of thiscompany—I went down on the morning of the 7th, as far as Blackwall—Mr. Farr brought a lady on board—I saw a chest on board—the lady saw it, and identified it as her property.
(M'Cormack and Sloane received good characters.)

M'CORMACK—
GUILTY . Aged 26. SLOANE—
GUILTY Aged 27.
Recommended to mercy by the Jury.
Confined Six Months.

SMITH—
NOT GUILTY .

1994.
GEORGE SMITH was again indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of july, 2oz. weight of tobacco, value 6d., the goods of
John Soy, in, the Royal Adelaide, on the navigable river Thames.
MESSRS. CLARKSON. and BALLANTINE. conducted the Prosecution.
JOHN BARTLETT . I am a Thames police-constable. I was called on

board the Royal Adelaide, on the 6th of July—I searched Smith, and found on him two ounces of tobacco—he was given into my custody, but he escaped—I asked him where he got the tobacco—he said he took it out of a cask.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLITS. Q. Did he not tell you there was a cask with a piece broken out of the head, and that he put his hand in and took that bit, thinking it was no harm? A. Yes, he did—the price of this is about 6d.

GEORGE WHITE . I am a Thames police-constable. I went in search of Smith—I took him into custody in the head sheets of a coal-barge-he said he had tried to get away from me, but he found it was of no use.
THOMAS COYLE . The name of the captain of the Royal Adelaide, is John Soy—I recollect receiving two hogsheads of tobacco on hoard, which were rather broken at the head.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined One Month.

1995.
HUMPHREY TAYLOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of August, 1 bag, value 2d.; and 102 pairs of iron tips, value 5s.; the goods of
James Bold.

JAMES BOLD . I live in Parker-street, Drury-lane, and am a smith. On the 2nd of August I was with the prisoner in Long-lane—I had 112 pairs of tips in a bag—we had called at one shop, and he said he had sold one pair-when we came to Long-lane, we went into a public-house, and laid the bag on the table—the prisoner took it up, and ran away, and left me to pay for a pint of porter—I saw him again on the 17th.

Prisoner. I gave him an order for six or eight dozen pairs off 3/4 plates—I found him on the 2nd of August, in Drury-lane, with the work, and he gave me the bags. Witness. No, I deny it—he carried it sometime—he had given me no orders for the tips—I was going out with them to sell—I did not say, "You can look at them, and see if they suit your order"—I had not got them for him.

Prisoner. We went to a public-house, and I picked one dozen out that were suitable—I took 1s., and we went and got dinner to
gether, and some ale, out of the shilling. Witness. No, I deny it—he dragged my work off the table, and said to the landlord, "I will leave this man in pawn for ten minutes"-! did not authorise him to sell a shilling's-worth at Mr. Cuthbert's, on this order he is speaking about, he took the work and had eighteen shillings for them, and he gave me but eight shi
lings for them—that was another matter.
JOHN RADLEY . (police-constable F 24.) I heard a cry of "Stop thief," at the corner of Queen-street, Seven Dials, on the 17th of August, and saw the prisoner running—I took him.

Prisoner. I had sold a shilling's-worth, and we went and drank, and ate together, and that night I sold eighteenpence worth more, at three-halfpence a pair—they were not worth going about with, and the Alderman ordered me to pay five shillings—I never was fetched to pay it, and them another Alderman ordered me to come here.
JAMES BOLD . re-examined. The tips were in a small leather bag, worth twopence, and the tips were worth 5s.—he was not to sell them—I let him off as low as I could, that he might make the money up.

GUILTY . Aged 57.—
Confined Three Months.

1996.
WILLIAM HENRYFRY was indicted
for bigamy.
The witnesses not appearing, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

1997.
WILLIAM HENRY FRY was again indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of February, 1 pair of boots, value 11s., the goods of
Edwin Bil
ton, his master.
MR. DOANE. conducted the Prosecution.

EDWIN BILTON . I am a boot and shoemaker, and live in Totten-ham-coart-road. The prisoner came into my service about sixteen months since—I missed a large quantity of property, and suspected him—I watched when he came from dinner, and communicated with Thornton, an officer-in the 17th of February I was in a room above looking through a hole in the ceiling-when he returned from dinner, between one and two o'clock, I observed him come to the corner of his board—he put his hat on the board and looked at the door—he crossed the shop to where I keep my boots and shoes, looked through the boots, and selected one boot—he had some difficulty to find the other—he found it in the window—he fetched two sheets of paper, and then keeping an eye to one door through which he thought I could see him, he rolled up one and put it into his coat-pocket—he had a large frock-coat on—he then took the other, wrapped that up, tried it round with string, and put it into his pocket—he then patted his lockets, put on his apron, crossed the shop, and hung up his hat which he had before laid on the board—I then communicated with the officer—I same down and told the prisoner to go to Soho-square—he left the shop, and I afterwards saw him in custody—these are my boots—(looking at them)—they were made for a customer, who, trying to get them on, burst own the back of one of them.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDEROAST. Q. you had him taken to Hatton garden? A. Of course—the Magistrate' differed in opinion with-before I had half gone through my case, he dismissed the charge—I him again apprehended at the office door—he was running away, and officer took him—the officer said, "You have three charges; this only one; you can take him again"—we then went to Bow-street—Mr. Twyford was the Magistrate there—he did not hear all I had to say—he said, "I cannot hear all a brother Magistrate has done; etiquette compels me to discharge him"—he said that there were three charges, and he wondered how Mr. Bennett could discharge him.

Q. Did you not admit that the prisoner had on other occasions taken boots and shoes from your shop without your knowing any thing about it, and had settled with you for them on Saturday night? A. No; I have served him twice as a customer—I stated that he had asked me for a pair of shoes for his sister, and another pair, soiled, for a servant, which I sold. him very cheap—I did not state that he took them out of the stock with-. out my knowledge, or without asking me—he said, "Can you let me have a soiled pair of shoes?" and I said, "Here are some soiled ones you can have at half-a-crown"—I said he had shoes out of my shop, and settled with me on Saturday night; and Mr. Bennett said, "He is not an honest man; he ought to have told you of these"—the prisoner had no customers of his own, to my knowledge—I had spoken to a policeman after I saw-him take first pair, before he took this pair—I had told the policeman

on Friday, and this occurred on the Saturday; but the policeman had been there the whole week—I had not had the prisoner taken up be
fore-no one came to me for a reference—I did not know that he was en
gaged by a shoemaker at Norwich—he had mentioned nothing about lear
ing my situation.

Prisoner. You said you would divide customers with me, and you knew I was going to Norwich-you said you would serve me out for it—you know I had one pair of boots for three months when the lady was out of town. Witness. No; you had a pair of shoes for three months, and I said he must pay on the Saturday night, if he did not return them.
COURT. Q. Had you previously known of his having them? A. Yes I had given him leave—I did not know who they were for.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Have you never sworn that you never served him but twice, and then as a customer? A. No; I should say I did not say so—I said, "I let him have two pairs—I served him on two occasions—he told me he knew a friend who would be very glad to purchase them, as they were an exceedingly strong pair, and if I would allow him, he would take them to try—he kept them, saying the party was at Richmond, and he could not get them—he never had boots or shoes from me, except the three pairs I have mentioned, to my recollection.

Q. Has he not had goods as many as half a dozen times, and settled with you for them on Saturday night? A. He has not half a dozen time—I think I am quite safe in swearing it was not five times—it may have been four times—I may have been mistaken in one—I preferred the charge before the Grand Jury—the prisoner has not been committed by any Ma
gistrate.

COURT. Q. When did you prefer your bill? A. On the 17th of April, I believe, while the Grand Jury were sitting—I have never had him ap
prehended.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. What was the reason you did not take him? A. I could not find him—I waited outside his mother's house while the officer went in—I did not go to his mother's house for him after that—I told the policeman to keep a look-out—I heard he was driving a cab, and I kept looking at the cabs—it was after the second hearing that I went to Bow-street—the week before he was taken, he returned me the pair of ladies' shoes that did not fit the customer-his mother did not appear when he was before Mr. Bennett, and bring forward a pair of shoes, that I saw—there was no pair brought forward that had been part of my stock—I swear it was not so—she did not produce a pair of boots—I did not see her within sufficient distance to produce anything—she stated no
thing there—I swear that without her being heard Mr. Bennett dismissed the prisoner—he was taken up ultimately on the charge of bigamy—he was remanded twice, I believe—I did not tell my story there before the Magistrate—I handed in the certificate of his being indicted.

MR. DOANE. Q. you had got your bill found by the Grand Jury? A. Yes; that was by the advice of Mr. Twyford-all the settlements I had with the prisoner alluded to the boots and shoes I had sold him—I never allowed him to take boots or shoes out without my consent.

GEORGE THORNTON . (police-constable E 91.) In consequence of di
rections from the prosecutor, I was in attendance outside his shop, on the 17th of February—he made some communication to me—the prisoner went

up Chenis-street into Gower-street—I went up to him, and asked what he had got in his pocket—he said, "Halloo, what do you want?"—he said, "My own property"—I said, "Where did you bring them from?"—he said, "I am not going to tell you"—I took one boot from one pocket, and the other from the other—I said, "Tell me where you are going to take these"—he said, "I shall not, I shall tell your superiors."

Cross-examined. Q. You were at Hatton-garden? A., Yes; the prosecu
tor said that six months before, the prisoner had said, "Have you got a pair of soiled shoes for my mother's servant?" and he gave him five pairs—that he brought four pairs back, and paid him for one—he said he might have told him one more pair—Mr. Bennett said he thought there had been a bona fide transaction, and if he were on a Jury, he should have a doubt whether he did not take these boots for the purpose of selling them—the prosecutor's shop opens with folding doors—there is a blind goes before the cutting-board—the prosecutor had come to me on Friday evening, and requested me to witch—he said, very likely there would be something done then, as he had taken a pair the day before, and had not given him any account of them—I had been watching two or three days before—he requested me to come early on the Saturday, and follow the prisoner.

MR. PRENDERGAST. to EDWIN BILTON. Q. Was not the prisoner re
gularly employed in selling boots and shoes in your shop? A. Certainly; he was my clicker—he was employed to cut out leather, and if an extra hand was wanted, be went in to sell—he took money—I had employed him ten months.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Three Months.
Fifth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1998.
ANN DAVIES was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of July, 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 watch-ribbon, value 2d.; 1 shirt, value 2s.; and 1 waistcoat, value 5s.; the goods of
Daniel Evans.

DANIEL EVANS . I am a servant, and live with Benjamin Hall. On the 30th of July I met the prisoner in Edgeware-road, about half-past eleven o'clock, or after—I was not quite sober—I entered into conversation with her—I cannot say whether she spoke to me first, or I to her—I took her to my room over the stable, in Old Church-street, Paddington—I gave her 2s. 6d.—we went to bed together, about twelve o'clock—I awoke about four o'clock the next morning, and she was gone—I looked on the table, and missed my watch—I went to the next room, and saw there was a shirt taken off the back of the chair, and this waistcoat—the watch was found—this is it—(looking at it).

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you in service? A. I was—I went by the name of Daniel Evans, but no other name—I swear that—I live at No. 22, Old Church-street, Paddington, with Mr. Benjamin Hall—I was not in that house by the name of David—I never answered to it—the prisoner asked me for gin—I told her she might have what she liked, and I would pay for it, and she had what she thought proper—I believe she called for half-a-pint, or sixpennyworth, or something of that sort, I do not know the measures—I do not know how much gin she drank, but what she called for, I paid for—we went to the Wheatsheaf, at the corner of old church-street—I gave her leave to call for what she liked—I cannot say whether I took any—I had taken a few pints of ale before-what I had

drank affected my head, of course, or else I should be able to answer about the drink-between myself and my friend we might drink four or five pints of ale-a very little would affect me-to the best of my knowledge I paid fivepence or sixpence for the prisoner—I do not believe that it was a shilling. I cannot swear it—lam sure she did not drink half-a-crown's worth of gia, because I had not so much in my pocket-when I went to the public-house I had about eightpence or ninepence—I was not sober when I went into the public-house—I was sober when I went to the first public-house—I there spent about eighteenpence—I had half-a-crown when I went there.

Q. Then you must have had a shilling when you left? A. Yes but I might have spent it elsewhere-if I see any thing in the street I may buy it—I cannot say whether I did buy any thing—the prisoner's sister has called on me—I sent a man to see for her, when I understood she wanted to see me—the man's name was Jones—I never went to her sister's resi
dence—I found she was looking for me two or three times at a public-house, and I sent to see what she had got to say—I went to see her three or four hours afterwards—I never said I never went to see her.

ALFRED BLUNDELL (police-constable E 24.) On Saturday, the 4th of August, I met the prisoner in Devonshire-street, Marylebone—that was some five days after this occurred—I told her I wanted her—she said, "For what?"—I said, "For robbing that man you went home with on Monday night"—she said, "It could not be me"—I said, "You are the person I saw in company with him"—she said, "I was not out on Monday night"—I took her to the station-house, and just before I got there she asked if she could see the man privately—I asked, "What man?"—she said the man she was with on Monday night—I said, What do you want to see him for?"—she made no answer—she again said, "Can I speak to him?" I said, "What do you want to speak to him for?"—she said, "I know nothing about any thing but the watch"—I said, "Don't you know about the other things?"—she said, "No"—I said, "If you know about the watch, you must know about the other things"—she then said that she had got the shirt at home, and the waistcoat her husband had got—I went to her room with her, and she gave me the duplicate of the watch, which was sewn up in a window-curtain—I have the shirt and waistcoat.
CHARLES FOWLER . I am journeyman to a pawnbroker. I have the watch—I cannot swear it was the prisoner who pawned it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1999.
GEORGE JOHNSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of August, 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
William Doo.

WILLIAM DOO . I am a tailor, and live in Poland-street. On the 11th of August, at half-past seven o'clock in the morning, I was at Covent Garden fruit-market—I felt a tug, turned, and saw the prisoner in custody of an officer, who had this handkerchief, which is mine—(looking at it.)

THOMAS BLASSETT . I am a constable. I saw the prisoner go behind the prosecutor, and take this handkerchief from his pocket—I went and took it from his left-hand trowsers pocket, and found another handkerchief on him.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Months.

2000.
ANN CONLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of Au
gust, 3 sovereigns, 5 shillings, and 3 sixpences, the monies of
Thomas Jackson, from his person.

THOMAS JACKSON . I have been in the 80th regiment of foot eight years—I left the regiment in New South Wales, but was discharged at Chatham—on the 10th of August I was in London, and fell in with the prisoner, about six o'clock in the afternoon, in Covent Garden—she was walking up the street—I was never in London before, and I asked her if she could tell me where I could get decent lodgings—she said she could get me lodgings—I told her if it was a decent house I would be obliged to her to show me, and I would pay her for her trouble—I treated her with a pot of beer, and gave her a small portion of gin—we then went to a house—we had a few words, and I gave her a crown for herself, and two shillings I paid for the room—we went up stairs, and went to bed—I folded up my trowsers, and placed them under the bolster—I had three sovereigns, five shillings, and three sixpences, which I had placed in my fob-pocket—I went to bed about a quarter before eight o'clock—I Was a little fatigued with travelling—I was just feeling drowsy, when I felt something raise my head—I might have been in bed three-quarters of an hour—I got up and felt, and my trowsers were not where I had placed them I found them on the floor—I felt in the fob, and the money was gone—I accused her of taking it—she was in the room, on the floor, not in bed—I had a few words with her, and she said she had not seen any money of mine—I called out for a policeman to be brought in—the police-man came, and I gave her in charge—there was one sovereign and two sixpences found, and one penny.

SARAH WHITE . I am servant at the house in question. The prosecu
tor came with the prisoner—I knew her before, but the man was a stranger—he came about half-past six o'clock, and paid me two shillings for the first-floor room—the prisoner came down in about a quarter of an hour with a sovereign, and asked me to get something to drink—I told her it was not allowed in the house—she went up stairs again—she had her stays, shift, and petticoat on—I cannot say whether she had her shoes on.

JOHN KNIGHT . (police-constable F 21.) About nine o'clock, on the 10th of August, I was called to No. 3, Legg-alley, to take in charge the prisoner for robbing the prosecutor—I went up stairs, and found them both undressed—the prisoner found a sovereign, and gave it to me—I found a sixpence and a penny in the room—the prosecutor had had a little drink, but was not tipsy.

Prisoner's Defence. I met this man in Seven Dials, very drunk, with another soldier—he had a bundle, I said, "You will lose the bundle if you don't take care"—it dropped, and I took it up—he said, "You take care of it, I will reward you for it"—he went into one public-house—they would not serve him, he was so tipsy—he went into another, and had a Pot of beer, and a glass of gin for me—he then went to another, and had mother pot of beer, and a quartern of gin—he pulled out a sovereign and some silver, and the other man said, "Take care of your little money, and get yourself a comrade"—he then said, "Come, I will show you where I "lodge"—they went out for about ten minutes, leaving me and another woman, and the bundle—the prosecutor came back—he asked me to get him a lodging—I took him up Long Acre—he went to a house, and paid two shillings for a bed—I went up stairs and took the bundle, and when we went

up, having the drop of gin, I suppose, I did not know what I was doing, no more than he did—it was then about eight o'clock-about nine o'clock I insisted upon going, finding where I was, and what a disgrace I had brought on myself, to pick up with such a low wretch—he got up, and said I should not go home—he took my pocket that was on the floor, and said, "Now you may go"—I said, "You sha'n't have my money, there's a half-crown and threepence-halfpenny in it—I insisted upon having the pocket—he got out of bed, and struck me, and gave me two black eyes—he struck me more than a dozen times—I hallooed murder—the servant came up, and he banged the door in her face, and said he would bung her eye—the housekeeper then came up, and said, "I can't have this noise, I must bare the police up stairs"-two policemen came up, and the prosecutor gave me is charge-first he said he had lost a sovereign, and then he said he had lost three sovereigns-when I said I wished to go, he dropped some money in the bed, the jingle of it was no more than a sovereign and a shilling-when the policemen searched, the bed-clothes were taken up, the sovereign and one sixpence were found in the mattress—I took up the sovereign, and said, "Here is a sovereign," and then the policemen took me to Bow-street-while the prosecutor was striking me, he dropped a sixpence, which was picked up at the water-stand, but he had given me two sixpences for myself—he did not give me five shillings-when I was searched, I had nothing about me but the two sixpences—the officer was sent back to the house to fetch the woman, and she had one pound, eight shillings, or one pound, eighteen shillings, in her pocket—the prosecutor said he had re
turned from transportation.
COURT. to THOMAS JACKSON. Did you tell her you had returned from transportation? A. No, I lost my arm in the service, and got discharged with a pension.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2001.
THOMAS ELDRIDGE and
GEORGE THAKES were indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of August, 1 jacket, value 5s., the goods of
Edmund Frederick Wright, in a certain vessel, in a certain port of entry and discharge.

HENRY MOORE . I am a labourer in the West India Docks. On the 23rd of August, I was at work in No. 1. warehouse—I saw the two prisoners coming round the corner, and stopped between two piles of wood, and I saw Thakes give Eldridge a jacket—he put it on-Thakes then said, "That will do, come on"—I met Mr. Stevenson, and told him.

ROBERT STEVENSON . I am a wharfinger in the Docks. Moore pointed out the two prisoners as they were coming towards the gate which leads out-Eldridge had the jacket on his back—they separated at the gate of the Export dock, then Eldridge took off the jacket, came towards me with it on his arm, and I took him.

JAMES COX . The two prisoners were given into my custody—I asked Eldridge if the jacket belonged to him—he said no, it was given to him by a man, but he did not know his name—I asked Thakes if he knew any thing of it—he said it was his, that he brought it to the Docks with him that morning.
EDMUND FREDERICK WRIGHT . I work on board a ship in the Docks. I left this jacket, which is mine, in the forecastle—I do not know the prisoners.
Eldridges Defence. I was unfortunately drawn into this—I have worked there fifteen years-in coming up, I heard a voice call "Halloo"—I

turned and saw this prisoner—he said, "Are you going to the Import Dock?"—I said "yes"—he said, "will you take this jacket up?"—It said—I "It is cold, I will put it on"—I went on to the Export-gate and stood there in the presence of the constable-finding the jacket was wet, I put it off, and stood there with it on my arm—the constable asked how I got the jacket—I told what I knew of it, that a man gave it me.

Thakes's Defence. If I had been on board the ship and stolen it, it is likely I should give it to this man to go to the gate where the officers—I was walking in the Docks, and saw a man who asked me to buy—I laid, "Did you come by it honestly?" he said, "Yes"—I said I did not want it—I gave him 6d. for it.
(Eldridge received a good character.)

ELDRIDGE—
GUILTY . Aged 45.

THAKES—
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Six Weeks.

2002.
EDWARD DODMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of August, 1 bridle, value 10s., the goods of
John Osborne.

WILLIAM ARNOLD . (police constable D 84.) On the 23rd of August, a little before nine o'clock, I met the prisoner in Portman-square, about a quarter of a mile from Mr. Osborne's—he said, "It is a fine morning"—I saw part of a bridle between his waistcoat and shirt—I ran after him, and said, "What have you got there?" he said, "A bridle"—I said, "Who does it belong to?"—he said, his friend, but would not tell me who—I took him to the station-house, and found this bridle, part under his jacket, and part in his hat—he then said some friend gave it him in Montague-square.

WIILIAM SMITH . I am ostler to Mr. John Osborne. I know the prisoner—he had been in Mr. Osborne's employ, but had left him, and worked for a man in the Mews—this is Mr. Osborne's bridle—it was taken from the boxes where the horses were.
Prisoner. I was not in the boxes that morning—I was only sweeping the yard.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Confined One Month.

2003.
JOSEPH GARDENER and
BENJAMIN NADEN were indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of August, 25 yards of printed cotton, Moore pointed value 6s. 6d. the goods of
Walter Brown Pretty; to which Gardener pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

THOMAS HODGE . I am in the employ of Walter Brown Pretty, a linen
draper, in Goswell-road. On the 23rd of August, I was standing inside the door, and saw the prisoner Naden in company with Gardener—there was a box with some prints on it—Gardener took some and ran off—the prisoner ran off with him—I took Gardener and took the print from his arm, another young man ran with me, and took Naden in Ashley-street.
THOMAS LILLEY . I am a policeman. I was at the corner of Eyre-street,
and saw the other boy run off with this print in his arms, and the prisoner ran with him.

NADEN—
GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Whipped and Discharged.

2004.
RICHARD GRAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of June, 1 coat, value 3l. 10s., the goods of
Robert Barr, his master.

ROBERT BARR . I am a tailor, and live in Slater-street. The prisoner was in my service—I went out on the 6th of June, and left him at work-when I returned, the prisoner and the coat were gone—I have never found it—he left me without notice, and I never saw him till he was in Worship. street.

WILLIAM BURN . I am a weaver. Mr. Barr made me a coat—I tore it—I took it to the prosecutor's on Wednesday, and he was out—I went away, and met him—we went back to his house in about an hour and a half, and the prisoner and the coat were gone—the prisoner was left at home.
WILLIAM HANKS . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner at Balls-pond, Islington, in August—I was looking for him the whole of June and July.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

2005.
WILLIAM COOK was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of August, 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Joseph Jay, from his person.

JOSEPH JAY . I am a plumber, and live in Upper Whitecross-street About half-past ten o'clock at night, on the 11th of July, I was standing in Upper Whitecross-street, having some oysters for my supper—Mr. Harm an ran by me, and said I had had my pocket picked—he ran up the court, and caught the prisoner—I have not seen my handker
chief since—I had used it three minutes before, and put it into my pocket.

CHARLES HARMAN . I Live in Whitecross-street. I was standing at my shop door, and saw the prisoner and another boy go by—I saw them pass by the prosecutor, and as the prisoner passed he touched his pocket, then turned back and picked the prosecutor's pocket—the other one stood by the prosecutor, and lighted his pipe by the gas—the prisoner then ran off—I do not know what became of the handkerchief, but I am sure I saw the prisoner take it.
Prisoner. I was going home, and this man said I took the handkerchief.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.

2006.
MARY BROOKS was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of August, 1 pewter pot, value 2s., the goods of
Thomas Smith.

HENRY MILLS . I live with Mr. Thomas Smith, at the Coach and Horses, in High-street, Shadwell. About six o'clock, on the 17th of August, the prisoner came and called for half a pint of beer—I served her with it in a pint pot—she sat by the side of the bar, and there was a quart pot that some one had left-when I turned she and the pot were gone—I went and found her with the quart pot, and took her back—this is my master's pot.
JAMES MARTIN . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner, and found the quart pot under her shawl, under her arm.

Prisoner. I had no shawl on—there was full half a pint of beer in the pot—I just took it outside the door to give to my daughter. Witness. there was a little beer in the bottom of the pot—she was one hundred and fifty yards from the house.

Prisoner. Some persons were drinking out of a quart pot—they went away and said, "Old lady, there is a little beer for you"—I emptied the half pint into the quart pot, and went to look for. my daughter outside—I was not two doors from the house.
JURY. to JAMES MARTIN. Q. Was the pot entirely covered with the Shawl? A. Yes.

GUILTY . Aged 47.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Three Months.

2007.
HANNAH NICHOLAS was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of August, 1 kettle, value 5s., the goods of
Christopher Galvin.

CRIISTOPHER GALVIN . I keep the Coach and Horses public-house, in Bartholomew Close. On the 15th of August, the prisoner came in for a half a pint of beer-when she was gone the kettle was missed, and two hours after wards the policeman brought it back—it had been on the tap-room fire with water in it—this is it—(looking at it).

CHARLOTTE TAYLOR . I was going down New-street, Cloth-fair, a little after six o'clock, on the 15th of August, and saw the prisoner with somthing in her apron—she went on before me, sat down upon a stone, and poured water out of the kettle, and wrapped it up in her apron—I followed her down Chiswell-street, and gave her in charge to the police
man.

GUILTY . Aged 61.—
Confined One Month.

2008.
THOMAS SHAW was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of August, 4 boots, value 1l., the goods of
George Hollingsworth.

GEORGE HOLLINGSWORTH . I keep a shoe shop, in High-street, Camden-town. On the 21st of August, about eight o'clock in the even
ing, I was in my shop—I cast my eye to the window, and the prisoner was taking my boots away—they were on the pane of the window outside—he had got these four down—(looking at them)-and there were four others missing—he ran off, and—I ran and took him-two of these are odd ones—the others are a pair—I have lost four others—I was told there were two other persons with the prisoner, but I did not see them.
JAMES RICHARDS . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner.

GUILTY . † Aged 25.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2009.
MARY HOLLAND was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of July, 4 spoons, value 20s.; 1 pair of sugar-tongs, value 3s. 6d.; 1 counter-pane, value 5s.; 1 table-cloth, value 3s. 6d.; 2 pairs of boots, value 4s.; I blanket, value 2s.; 2 petticoats, value 2s.; 1 towel, value 6d.; and 1 napkin. value 3d.; the goods of
Ann Lydia Lane.

ANN LYDIA LANE . I am a widow, and live in Whitecross-place, Wil
son-street. I get my living by hot-pressing—the prisoner has lived in the nighbourhood for some years—on the 16th of July she represented to me that she was in great distress, and asked permission to see a person who lay dead in my house-in passing from the parlour to the kitchen, she

said I had a great deal to do—I said I had—she said she should be happy to assist me—I said I did not want a person—she said she should be glad to do any thing; that her husband had turned her out, and she wanted a meal—I thought it very hard, and I allowed her to come to my house, and gave her food and employment—she continued there till the 18th—I then missed a spoon, and then several other articles; but I did not suppose them lost, because she was every meal thanking me for my kindness—I thought, having a young family of five orphan children depending upon me for support, that the things might be mislaid—I missed a great many articles, and on the 9th of August, I ascertained that the prisoner had taken some things—on the 10th I asked her about it—she denied it, and wished the Lord might strike her dead if she had robbed me—I said, "If you have ventured your body, do not venture your soul"—she said, there were other persons in the house—I said, "Yes; but they have been in the house a long time"—I then told her I had proved her to be a thief—after a great deal of talk she gave me some duplicates-while I was talking to her she absconded through the next house without a bonnet.
ANN COLLINGHAM . I searched the prisoner in Featherstone-street station-house—on the 10th of August I found fourteen duplicates upon her—they relate to this property.

JAMES FRANCIS THOMPSON . I am a pawnbroker. I have ten pledges which I took in of the prisoner mostly—I have a spoon, a petticoat, some holland, a towel, an apron, a pair of boots, a napkin, a handkerchief, another petticoat, a pair of sugar-tongs, salt-spoon, dessert-spoon, and table-spoon—they are not all my taking in-but I took in several of then from the prisoner.

GEORGE ATTENBOROUGH . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Crown-street. I have a pair of shoes, a blanket, and counterpane—I cannot say I took them from the prisoner; but these duplicates correspond with the articles.
SUSANNAH LANE . I live with the prosecutrix, who is my mother.

Prisoner. Q. Did I not come into the passage when the spoon was pawned, and ask you where your mother was, and you said very likely she was gone to Bow-street; and I said, "Your mother gave me a spoon to pledge?" A. No.
WILLIAM BRILL . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner, and twelve duplicates were found upon her.
ANN LYDIA LANE . re-examined. All this is my property—it is part of what I lost.

Prisoner. Q. On your oath, was not the first thing you gave me to pledge that silver spoon-you asked Mrs. Batty to pay you your rent—she said she must make the money to pay you, and then you gave me the spoon to pledge? A. No, I did not.

Prisoner. When I came in with the money for the spoon she was gone out, and I asked the little girl which way she went—I gave her the silver and the halfpence in the market. Witness. I never gave her any thing to pawn, and never had the money.

Prisoner. She gave me the halfpence, and brought home a leg of pork to dine with a tally-man that comes every other week to dine with her and then she went into the country-when she returned, she told me to get a leg of pork and some peas, and to make a currant pie—she left no money in the house—I said, "What am I to do?"—she said, "Do as boy can, as I took a counterpane, and got 5s.—her little boy

and another went with me to Mr. Chappell's, in Fore-street, and she came home the next morning intoxicated—the sugar-tongs she gave me the morning she was going into the country with a pot-boy—they offered me 3s. for them—I came back and said, "Mrs. Lane, Mr. Thompson won't give me but 3s. "—she said, "That won't do to go so many miles with," she got the damask cloths, and I went to Mr. Attenborough's, and got 3s. on each of them-and I went and bought half a pound of beef, a quarter of a pound of ham, and a quartern of shrub, and they took them with them—she came home next morning, and had breakfast and gin-and-cloves, and then she set off into the country again—then she saw a pair of old boots, and gave me the money to go and get them—she asked me for the tickets—I was washing a child, and said, "You are not in such a hurry"—she said "If you do not give me them this moment, I will chop your hands from your arms"—I did not mind her passion, because she had taken the toasting fork that morning, and beat her child all about the house because the cat broke the pie dish, and that was the game all day, till Mr. M'Gear, the tally-man, came, and then we were all ushered out of the room—I put down the account of the things I bought, and gave her child the paper, and said I had spent the money to the best advantage—she never asked where the things were got so long as she got them, and got the money to go into the country with that pot-boy.

ANN LYDIA LANK
re-examined. Q. Is it so? A. It is quite false—I never gave her authority to pawn any goods—there is no truth in her statement—there were twenty-six duplicates found—I took her out of Charity.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2010.
MARY ANN FOSTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of August, 1 pair of stays, value 2s.; 2 basins, value 8d.; 1 plate, value 4d.; 1 yard of silk, value 1s.; and 1 yard of patch-work, value 1s.; the goods of
Elizabeth Wright-2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of the
ordinary of the Diocese.

ELIZABETH WRIGHT . I am a widow. I live at No. 6, Turville's-buildings, Turville-street, Bethnal-green—my husband died on the 2nd of August—the prisoner came to our house several times to fetch a few errands, as we were all laid up with a fever—we were all so bad we could not get out of bed—on the 2nd of August she came in and asked me if I would let her sit down in my room where I lodged—I left her in care of that room—my little girl is eleven years old—I was gone from half-past ten till eleven o'clock—this property was taken from my box—it was not locked—my husband was lying dead in the bed—I lost a pair of stays, two basins, a plate, a yard of silk, and some patch-work-when I returned the prisoner was gone, and the room was in darkness—I saw her again on the Thursday following, seven or eight days afterwards—these stays and basins are mine.

JOHN WILSON . I keep a chandler's shop. The prisoner brought these stays and basins to my shop, and asked if I would let her have a few pro
visions on them, to the amount of 6 1/2 d.—this was on the evening of the 2nd of August.

FREDERICK EAGER . I am a policeman. I went in search of the pri
soner, and found her eight days afterwards, in Kingsland-road, in a state of great distress, and in a bad state of health—I know she has no place to
live in or to go to—she sleeps about in the brick-fields, or any where she can.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2011.
JAMES VANNER was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of August, 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
Frederick Forbes King, from his person.

FREDERICK FORBES KING . I reside with my parents. On the 11th of August I was in Shore ditch, about two o'clock in the afternoon, standing buying some gooseberries—I felt something at my pocket—I turned and saw the prisoner—he took my handkerchief out of his breeches, and threw it into the gooseberry-basket—I took him.
Prisoner. I saw a woman selling oranges. I went up and saw the prosecutor—he took another boy first, and then he took me.

GUILTY . Aged 14.-
Whipped and Discharged.

div0.p: Second Jury, before Mr. Justice Bosanquet.

div1.p:
2012.
ANGELINA POW was indicted (with
THOMAS MYERS not in custody,)
for the willful murder of
Thomas Davidson Pow, her husband.
MR. PRENDERGAST, on the part of the prosecutor, declined offering any evidence.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Coleridge.

2013.
JOSEPH FLACK was indicted
for a robbery on
Ann Lee, on the 4th of August, at St. Marylebone, putting her in fear, and taking from her person and against her will, 2 half-crowns, 2 shillings and 3 sixpences, her monies; and, immediately before and at the time of the said robbery, feloniously striking, beating, and using other personal violence to her; and that he had been previously convicted of felony.

ANN LEE . I live in Devonshire-place, Lisson-grove. I have been out of place for about a month and have walked the streets—on a Sunday morn
ing, about three weeks ago, between two and three o'clock, I went into a coffee-shop, down Stingo-lane, to have a cup of coffee—I saw the prisoner there—I did not know him before—he spoke to me and asked me to have some coffee—I said I had rather not, I had some of my own—I went down to the corner of Wilmot-street—he followed me out and caught hold of me by the body and knocked me down—I got up again and asked him what he meant—he made me no answer, but knocked me down again—I got up, and he hit me in the face and knocked me down a third time—he then tore my frock from my arm down to my skirt, and took two half-crowns, two shillings, and three sixpences, out of my pocket—I caught his hand at my pocket, and felt it about my thigh—after he knocked me down, he put his foot right down my body—he stamped on me—I hollowed "Police and murder!" and he was just running away, a gentleman stop
ped him, and the policeman directly came up and apprehended him-he

said he was very sorry, and if he had his liberty again he would kill me—I saw the policeman take him—I was only a little way from him—I did not lose sight of him—I kept up after him as fast as I could run—I had got the money that night-a gentleman gave it to me-as the prisoner look a shilling out of my pocket, I took a shilling out of his hand, as his hand was coining from my pocket, and that I showed at the station-house—I am sure he stamped on my breast—I had a black spot on my breast and on my face—I did not show it to anybody—I told the police of it at the station-house—there was a mark on my clothes just where he put his foot right down my body.

Prisoner. Did not I first meet you in the Grove, where you stood with a young woman? Witness. I never saw you in my life till I went into the coffee-shop—there was a young woman there named Mary Caton—she was in before me—I did not walk arm-in-arm with you—I did not accom
pany you to a closet, nor did you give me a shilling.

COURT. Q. Was there no talk about your going with him? A. No, I would not have gone with him, if he had offered me five shillings—I did not like the look of him—he did not make me any offer—he had the half-crown in his hand at the time I got the shilling from his hand-here were eight or nine people in the coffee-shop, but I only spoke to the girl.

HENRY WILLIAM BOXALL . I am a medical student, and live in High Holborn. On Sunday morning, the 5th of August, between two and three o'clock, I was in the New-road, near Wyndham-place—I heard a female screaming "Murder!"—I immediately ran to the place and found the prisoner running away towards the New-road, and a female pursuing him—I called for a policeman—he came up and I gave the prisoner in charge—I did no
thing to him myself—I ran against him and he stepped—the prosecutrix came up and accused him of robbing her of eight shillings and sixpence—he denied it, but said he had given her a shilling to go with him-her gown was torn from her shoulder down to her pocket-her hair seemed very much disordered and her bonnet bent—I did not observe any marks on her breast—she complained of having been struck and stamped upon, and said she had been thrown down three times—it was a dry night—I did not notice her dress whether it was dirty behind or not.

THOMAS KENNY . I am a policeman. On the night in question I was called for, and came up in the New-road, close to Lisson-grove—I heard the screams of a female, between two and three o'clock—I could not tell in what direction they were—I ran, and saw the prisoner running as fast as he could at the top of Wyndham-street, in the middle of the street—I put my hands forward, and caught him in my arms-in about five minutes the prosecutrix came up, apparently greatly fatigued, with her gown torn, from the right shoulder down to the waist—I asked her what was the matter—she told me the prisoner had robbed her of all she had in her pocket, and threatened to have her life—I asked him was it so, and his answer was he was sorry he did not murder her, and if ever he got out of my hands he would murder her—he did not say why—I asked the girl, in his presence, what was taken out of her pocket—she said she had in her pocket two half-crowns, two shillings, and three sixpences, and one of the shillings she snatched from his hand as he was robbing her—she gave me that shil
ling-while I was asking her about it the prisoner made several attempts to put his left hand into his left-hand trowsers-pocket—I prevented him,

and immediately took him to the station-house—on the way there he made several attempts to escape from me, till I called another constable to assist me—the prosecutrix stated at the station-house, in the presence of the pri
soner, myself, Mr. Boxall, and the Inspector, that she was robbed of two half-crowns, two shillings, and three sixpences, and that one of the shillings she had in her hand was one of them—I was holding the prisoner's left hand at the time—I searched his left-hand pocket, and found in it two half-crowns, one shilling, and three sixpences, and in the other pocket 2s. 8 1/2 d.;—the prosecutrix was unable to speak for a few minutes—she had been running some distance—I heard her screams for ten minutes before I took him—there was a mark over one of her eyes—the skin appeared to be broken—I did not observe any mark on her breast—it was a very dry night—I did not see any mark on her clothes—she said, at the station-house, that after she got up the third time, he struck her with his clenched hand, knocked her down, and made his escape—he still kept saying all the time that he would murder her-when she said she took one of her two shillings from his hand, he said that shilling he had given her to go with him—he said nothing more—he was very angry with me, and said neither I nor two more constables should take him.
Prisoner. Q. Who gave me into custody? A. Mr. Boxall—he ran to the girl, pointed you out, and I seized you—I heard her cries five minutes before you came up.

COURT. Q. Is it uncommon for girls of that sort to scream in the street? A. She screamed murder in such a curious way, I really thought there was murder—she was perfectly sober, and so was the pri
soner.

Prisoner's Defence. I met the woman at the corner of Devonshire-street, with another female—she asked where I was going—I said, "Home,"—she said, could I take her home with me, for at the lodging she lived they would not allow her to take men home—she said at the sta
tion-house that she had been at a brothel in Stafford-street, where a gentle
man gave her the money she charges me with robbing her of—she asked me to accompany her to Oxford-street to sleep with her for the night—I refused—she then asked me to go to a coffee-shop, which I did, sad paid for two cups of coffee, loaves and butter—after we came out I went down Stingo-lane with, her—the inspector of police met us, and a policeman named Thomas—I have sent for him, but he has not come—we were going on, arm-in-arm, in the road, and yet she swears I never met her till she got to the coffee-shop-at the office she said I had hold of her round the middle each time, and now she says I struck her violent blows—I have only to say she is doing it for nothing else but to make a property, and if yon will look at this paper it will prove it—(producing one)—it is a paper she has brought to my friends—she swore she would not come against me—it is my mother's writing, and she gave her 9s. 6d., which was 1s. more than she says she lost—I should like her asked about that.

ANN LEE (looking at the paper.) The prisoner's mother has been to me at different times, and she took me down to her place—she gave me 7s., and took me out with two more women, made me drunk, and took some of the money from me again—she gave me a silk handkerchief, and I allowed her 2s. 6d. for that to make up the money—she gave me the money not to come against the prisoner—I did not say I would not come against him—I wanted to come all the time—I took the money and said nothing—I knew

she meant it for me not to come—I did not say if she would give it me I would not come against him—she took me to three or four public-houses, and made me spend every halfpenny of the 7s. 6d. in liquor—I got so tipsy I was taken to the station-house—this was about a fortnight after the prisoner had been taken up—the policeman saw me tipsy, and took me and the mother to the station-house.

Prisoner. My brother went and fetched her out next morning. Witness. A young man who was with his brother went and paid 1s. for me—I was going to send home for 1s.—I did not know he was to pay the 1s.

ROBERT METCALF . I am a policeman. I have a certificate of ten pri
soner's former conviction—I had him in custody last August—he was tried here at the August Session, and convicted—(certificate read.)

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.
Before Mr. Justice Coleridge.

2014.
HENRY TRUMPSHAW, alias Drabshaw
, was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of August, at St. Pancras, 1 work-box, value 2l. 10s.; 1 ring, value 5l.; 1 measure, value 2s. 6d.; 1 penknife, value 4s. 6d.; 1 pair of scissors, value 4s. 6d.; 1 stiletto, value 2s. 6d.; 1 needle-box, vale 2s. 6d.; 12 reels, value 6s.; and 1 bodkin-case, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
Henry Beckley Richardson, in his dwelling-house.

HENRY BECKLEY RICHARDSON . I live at No. 1, Gothic Cottages, Park
village East, Regent's-park. On the 21st of August, a little before three o'clock, Host a work-box, which I had seen that morning on the loo
table in the drawing-room on the ground-floor—it contained the articles stated—the house is almost surrounded by a garden, and the street-door is kept open during the day—the garden-door was kept locked—I think I have some recollection of the prisoner—he has been a sweep, and I think has swept the chimneys in my house.

WILLIAM SIMPSON . I am pot-boy at the Victoria, in Crescent-place, Hampstead-road. The Gothic Cottages are just across the road—I know the prisoner. On Tuesday, the 21st of August, about twenty minutes after two o'clock, I saw him under Mr. Richardson's palings, with another boy—I did not see the other boy get over, but I missed him, and then I saw him hand the box over to the prisoner, who walked away with it—they went away together till they got to Augusta-street, and then they parted—I ran on and followed the prisoner with the box—they walked right up the Albany-road, and turned down by the canal—I ran round to see if I could see the prisoner again, but could see no more of him—I then ran and asked Mr. Richardson if he had lost any thing—I and the police
man went to look for him, but could not find him—I saw him in custody eight o'clock—the box seemed a dark one, with some white about it—it poured with rain at the time—I did not know whether I might take him, as I could not see a policeman.

WILLIAM PETTIT . I am a policeman. I produce a box which I found in the plantation adjoining the Regent's-canal, on Tuesday evening, about half-past seven o'clock—I heard the prisoner had been seen to go there, and I and my brother constable hid ourselves, to see who would come for it—just afterwards the prisoner came, and when about four yards from the box, I suppose he saw me—he had passed by the box, and was making

off from it—he did not run—my brother constable said, "You lay and watch the box, and I will take the prisoner to the pot-boy to see if he can identify him"—the prisoner then said, "That box I am sent for by a lad of the name of Bill Power, who lives in Somers-town"—he had got into the plantation, and was looking about—the key of the box was left at the sta
tion-house.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM SIMPSON
re-examined. I cannot say this is the same box I saw—it was about this size—the two boys came there about ten minutes after two o'clock—I did not watch them, but I turned my head and saw the other come over the palings, and hand the box to the prisoner as he was waiting under the palings, looking about.

Prisoners Defence. I was at home and in he bed at the time-what he says, is false-last Monday I and my brother were sent from home by the foreman of the gas-company, to see if we would come to work—we went—we were to have 3s. for it, and on Tuesday we laid a-bed together-about half-past six o'clock a young lad came to our place and said, "Harry, will you fetch a box?"—I said, "Where is it to come from?"—he said, "Come, and I will show you"—I said I was going to work at the gas-works—he said, "You won't he gone half an hour, and I will give you 6d. "—I asked if he came honestly by it—he said it was his—I went with him, and he said, "You need not carry it, only fetch it out to me, I am ordered to fetch it, and I am to have half a crown to fetch it, and will give you 6d. to fetch it out to me."
